channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Tribal Loyalties Drive Jordan’s Effort to Free Pilot
item.description: A Jordanian pilot captured by the Islamic State is a member of a politically influential tribe, part of a crucial base of tribal support for the king.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND and RANYA KADRI
item.media:credit: Warrick Page for The New York Times
item.media:description: Safi Youssef al-Kasasbeh, the father of a pilot held by the Islamic State, in Amman on Saturday.

item.title: Sisi Blames Muslim Brotherhood for Bombings in Sinai
item.description: President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi on Saturday declared that Egypt was “fighting the strongest secret organization of the last two centuries.”
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: As Ebola Ebbs in Africa, Focus Turns From Death to Life
item.description: In Liberia, where streets were littered with the Ebola dead just a few months ago, new cases are now numbering in the single digits, and people are returning to their routines.
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.dc:creator: By NORIMITSU ONISHI
item.media:description: Beachgoers in Monrovia, Liberia, recently ravaged by Ebola. As fear of the virus ebbs, Liberians are slipping back into their daily rhythm.

item.title: ISIS Says It Killed 2nd Japanese Hostage
item.description: A video shows the beheading of a journalist, Kenji Goto, killed a week after ISIS announced the killing of another Japanese hostage.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND
item.media:description: In its latest video, the Islamic State group said that it had beheaded another Japanese hostage, Kenji Goto, after a deadline for a prisoner swap expired.

item.title: Memo From London: Public Survey Highlights Britons’ Global Ambitions
item.description: Despite an election season that has seen little mention of defense and foreign policy issues, more than 60 percent of Britons surveyed believed the nation should remain a “great power.”
item.category: Chatham House (The Royal Institute of International Affairs)
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: World Briefing: Iraq: Militants Kill a Kurdish Commander Near Kirkuk
item.description: The commander, Brig. Gen. Hussein Mansour, was killed Friday night by a sniper near Kirkuk during clashes between Islamic State fighters and Kurdish security forces, known also as pesh merga.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Bahrain: 72 People Are Stripped of Their Citizenship
item.description: The government has revoked the citizenship of 72 Bahrainis as part of its responsibility to “protect the security and stability of Bahrain,” the Interior Ministry said Saturday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: West Bank: Israeli Forces Fatally Shoot a Palestinian
item.description: Israeli forces fatally shot one Palestinian and wounded another after they were spotted throwing a firebomb onto a road that is also used by Israeli settlers, the Israeli military said.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: World Briefing: Bangladesh: Factory Fire Kills at Least 13 People in the Capital
item.description: A fire swept through a plastic packaging factory on Saturday night in Bangladesh’s capital, Dhaka, killing at least 13 people, a fire department official said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Taliban Justice Gains Favor as Official Afghan Courts Fail
item.description: After paying bribes and enduring long delays while pursuing resolution in Afghanistan’s government courts, a growing number of citizens are turning to an informal justice system that includes tribal elders and the Taliban insurgents.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tribal elders hearing a case in Kandahar in December. Afghanistan’s informal justice system also includes Taliban courts.

item.title: Immigration Rules in Bahamas Sweep Up Haitians
item.description: A fiercely debated new immigration policy in the Bahamas requires everyone to hold a passport, a rule that human rights groups say unfairly targets people of Haitian descent.
item.dc:creator: By FRANCES ROBLES
item.media:credit: Andrea Bruce for The New York Times
item.media:description: According to a strict new immigration policy, schoolchildren like these two friends of Haitian descent who were born in the Bahamas will be required to have a student residency permit to attend school next fall.

item.title: Kel Nagle, 1960 British Open Winner, Dies at 94
item.description: Nagle, an Australian, staved off a rally at St. Andrews in Scotland to deny Arnold Palmer’s attempt to capture his third straight major title, and lost to Gary Player in a memorable playoff at the 1965 United States Open.
item.dc:creator: By BRUCE WEBER
item.media:description: Kel Nagle at the 1984 British Open.

item.title: Opinion: Lights Out in Nigeria
item.description: Bulbs dim. Fans slow. Once, my air-conditioner caught on fire.
item.dc:creator: By CHIMAMANDA NGOZI ADICHIE

item.title: DealBook: President of China Minsheng Bank Steps Down
item.description: The China Minsheng Banking Corporation gave no explanation for the resignation of Mao Xiaofeng and no indication whether he had been questioned or was assisting investigators.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID BARBOZA

item.title: Ukraine Fighting Continues as Talks Stall
item.description: Envoys representing Ukraine, Russia and a European monitoring group opened a new round of cease-fire talks in Belarus on Saturday, but without leaders of the Russian-backed separatists.
item.category: Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Clashes Intensify Between Armenia and Azerbaijan Over Disputed Land
item.description: Dozens of soldiers on each side have been killed and the countries are perilously close to open war.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: Richard von Weizsäcker, 94, Germany’s First President After Reunification, Is Dead
item.description: Mr. Weizsäcker became West Germany’s head of state in 1984 and served through the merger of East Germany into the Federal Republic of Germany before stepping down in 1994.
item.dc:creator: By WOLFGANG SAXON
item.media:description: From left: Richard von Weizsäcker, then the mayor of West Berlin; President Ronald Reagan; and Chancellor Helmut Schmidt in 1982 at the Berlin Wall.

item.title: Thousands March in Spain to Support Left-Wing Party
item.description: Saturday’s march was the most important rally organized by Podemos since it emerged as a newcomer in Spanish politics last May.
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER
item.media:description: Saturday’s march was the most important rally for Podemos since it emerged in Spanish politics.

item.title: Italy Elects President, While Mulling a Change in Role
item.description: Sergio Mattarella, a veteran politician and constitutional court judge, will be Italy’s next president, a post that is expected to be redefined during his tenure.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.media:description: The election of Sergio Mattarella, left, was seen as a victory for Prime Minister Matteo Renzi.

item.title: A Silver Lining Coated in Coal Dust in Eastern Ukraine
item.description: The rebel government has lifted a ban on private coal mining, a widespread practice in the financially struggling region.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
